title: Panel session: The Promise and Perils of Found Data

author: Ross Beveridge, Department of Computer Science, Colorado State University

segmentation: I'm not used to sticking next to a podium.
I'll see how close to the Mike I can stay.
I prepared about three different talks and then of course promised myself that I wouldn't give a talk.
I'll try to take, I think, about 8 minutes.
I first faced indecision as to whether to make this talk fun versus more formal, and I will show you.
The title slide to the talk you're not having 'cause this would be the fun one is found data truly treasure.
Do we have gems or worms?
And that was going to be an interesting talk, but instead.

Takes us to name this researcher.

Like about a decade before I met him and I would say about a decade before I watched him stand up before an entire CVP, our audience and harangue the daylights out of us and explain to the computer vision community.
Think this about 1988, nineteen, 90 that we didn't know the first thing about evaluation and he was sick of reading papers with three images and that there was the science anyway.
Um?
I actually had a lot of sympathy for what he was saying, although it was interesting to hear a brilliant mathematician, a brilliant researcher haranguing the
Of us.
So he put it in writing.
He threw out a gauntlet.
He wrote a paper and this is 94 performance characterization in computer vision.
And in there was the mantra that if you did computer vision.
What you had to do was explain.
I'll go back.
This way.
In analytical terms, what your algorithm did?
And that would be called a good engineer or a good scientist.
Well.
I don't know what possessed me as a pre PhD grad student to think that I should stand up to Bob Hair.
Looks like he wouldn't see a slide if I didn't admire him so much.
My colleague Bruce Draper and I wrote a response to his paper which was also published and we said you can't do that, sorry.
I could not wrap my brain around a full analytical model of the space of New England House scenes, which after all, is what we were working at the time.

I didn't know what such a mathematical model would look like, and therefore I like to think there was more in this response 20 years later than there probably was, but we were certainly arguing that what we really needed to work from was datasets that captured what we were doing and to take a more empirical scientific approach.
So.
I argued that then 21 years.
Later, let me now sort of cartoon characterize what we do.
We have it backwards.
Much of what is done in computer vision and in.
Papers here and by the way, by myself, I will make as much fun of myself as everyone else.
I will try very hard to do that, but we have it backwards.
What we tend to do is we take a set of algorithms.
That's what our capital X is.
It's not the domain model, it's a set of algorithms.
We pour it into a black box in that black box is a data set, and out pops a series of scores, performance measures, and now I will turn this.
Right side up, because that's a little less derogatory, and as I said, I do this too.
Why is a set of algorithms pour it into the black box outcomes scores and how many times have all of us published tables SVM?
Snoopy got 63% SVN Calvin got 69% mine.
It's always the last row and it's always the algorithm in the paper got 73.
This is The Who jumps hyest protocol.
I'm footnote Bob Haralick would have actually been partly happy to see this, because there's one thing that's good about this.
The black box that I use is same one that the people before me used.
That's actually an improvement in 20 plus years.
But it's still kind of a limited protocol.
It's still who jumped hyest, so.
I'm circling in on the real question.
The real question is what are we trying to accomplish and there's two sides.
One side of that I'm not going to talk about this.
I'm not going to talk about is you do begin with a hypothesis and problem.
I want to recognize schoolchildren sitting at a table interacting with a teacher.
You don't say I want to solve face recognition.
That second one is not a plausable goal.
You haven't said whether you're talking about people climbing Mount Everest or you're talking about ER patients as they're being admitted on gurneys.
I mean, the world has a nasty way of being very complicated, so there is that side of what we're trying to accomplish.
There's a different one, and yes, this is effectively a true story, slightly abbreviated.
I was deeply concerned with the 73 versus the 69, and I brought on Jeff Givens to work with us at CSU and in a meeting I was more or less once again saying.
When is 63 versus 69.
Sorry 73 verse 69 significant and I think in a moment of true impatience, he looked at me, said, wouldn't you rather know what contributes to the changes in performance?
And I was deeply humbled and I still remember that moment because I went.
Yeah, that is the more interesting question and.
In order to do that.
You have to know a lot more notice.
It's the same picture.
All I changed was the primes.
I love mathematical notation, you can hide almost everything.
This isn't the same box X in this case is data, but it's data with covariates, its data with the factors that you think might matter.
Camera F, stop, location, gender.
Where etc I'll go.
The F prime is a statistical model and what comes out is actually an explanatory model.
You can now say something about when I run an algorithm in this environment.
This is what's altering its behavior.
And of course if I can do it for one algorithm, I can do it for five or 10.
And now I'm beyond who jumps HIAS.
I'm actually characterizing the algorithms.
Told.
I'd circle around.
The perils and promises have found data.
I'm fundamentally agnostic that isn't really the issue.
The issue is.
Whether you find it collected design it will it take you beyond a simple who jump highest analysis.
Does it come with the additional information that you need to move on to the more interesting questions of what's causing the current technology to succeed fail do better here, worse there.
Now, selfishly, will point out.
There is one example of that here, and it's the person recognition evaluation.
We have covariates on sensors plus location action.
That's the single most predict.

That's the single most important factor beyond algorithm for varying expected verification performance of video, face recognition algorithms, and we couldn't do that if we didn't have a lot more than a pile of data.
